Name: adaptive_dropout
Title: Adaptive Dropout: Validation-Guided Dynamic Regularization for Language Models
Problem Statement: Fixed dropout rates and predefined schedules may not optimally respond to model's actual learning needs during training.
Motivation: Models could benefit from dropout rates that automatically adjust based on current validation performance, providing more regularization when needed (during periods of poor generalization) and less when the model is learning effectively.
Proposed Method: Implement an adaptive dropout mechanism that increases dropout when validation loss plateaus or worsens, and decreases it when validation improves, within defined bounds.
Experiment: Modify training loop to adjust model.dropout based on validation loss trends. Compare against fixed dropout baseline and predefined schedules. Track how dropout evolves during training and its impact on final performance.

title: What is the best recipe for character-level encoder-only modelling?
abstract: This paper aims to benchmark recent progress in language understanding models that output contextualised representations at the character level. Many such modelling architectures and methods to train those architectures have been proposed, but it is currently unclear what the relative contributions of the architecture vs. the pretraining objective are to final model performance. We explore the design space of such models, comparing architectural innovations and a variety of different pretraining objectives on a suite of evaluation tasks with a fixed training procedure in order to find the currently optimal way to build and train character-level BERT-like models. title: TinyHelen's First Curriculum: Training and Evaluating Tiny Language   Models in a Simpler Language Environment
abstract: Training language models (LMs) and their application agents is increasingly costly due to large datasets and models, making test failures difficult to bear. In these simplified language environments, workable strategies for small models, datasets, and agents may be adaptable to larger models, datasets, and agents in complex language environments.   To create such environments, we focus on two aspects: i) minimizing language dataset noise and complexity, and ii) preserving the essential text distribution characteristics. Unlike previous methods, we propose a pipeline to refine text data by eliminating noise, minimizing vocabulary, and maintaining genre-specific patterns (e.g., for books, conversation, code, etc.). Tiny LMs trained on these datasets outperform those trained on original datasets in instruction-following across different language granularity levels. Moreover, the Leaner-Pretrain dataset's alignment with conventional large LM training sets enables resource-optimized analysis of how learning objectives, model architectures, and training techniques impact performance on language modeling and downstream tasks. title: Toucan: Token-Aware Character Level Language Modeling
abstract: Character-level language models obviate the need for separately trained tokenizers, but efficiency suffers from longer sequence lengths. title: CharBERT: Character-aware Pre-trained Language Model
abstract: Most pre-trained language models (PLMs) construct word representations at subword level with Byte-Pair Encoding (BPE) or its variations, by which OOV (out-of-vocab) words are almost avoidable. However, those methods split a word into subword units and make the representation incomplete and fragile. In this paper, we propose a character-aware pre-trained language model named CharBERT improving on the previous methods (such as BERT, RoBERTa) to tackle these problems. We first construct the contextual word embedding for each token from the sequential character representations, then fuse the representations of characters and the subword representations by a novel heterogeneous interaction module. We also propose a new pre-training task named NLM (Noisy LM) for unsupervised character representation learning. We evaluate our method on question answering, sequence labeling, and text classification tasks, both on the original datasets and adversarial misspelling test sets. The experimental results show that our method can significantly improve the performance and robustness of PLMs simultaneously. Pretrained models, evaluation sets, and code are available at https://github.com/wtma/CharBERT

title: TinyStories: How Small Can Language Models Be and Still Speak Coherent   English?
abstract: Language models (LMs) are powerful tools for natural language processing, but they often struggle to produce coherent and fluent text when they are small. Models with around 125M parameters such as GPT-Neo (small) or GPT-2 (small) can rarely generate coherent and consistent English text beyond a few words even after extensive training. This raises the question of whether the emergence of the ability to produce coherent English text only occurs at larger scales (with hundreds of millions of parameters or more) and complex architectures (with many layers of global attention).   In this work, we introduce TinyStories, a synthetic dataset of short stories that only contain words that a typical 3 to 4-year-olds usually understand, generated by GPT-3.5 and GPT-4. We show that TinyStories can be used to train and evaluate LMs that are much smaller than the state-of-the-art models (below 10 million total parameters), or have much simpler architectures (with only one transformer block), yet still produce fluent and consistent stories with several paragraphs that are diverse and have almost perfect grammar, and demonstrate reasoning capabilities.   We also introduce a new paradigm for the evaluation of language models: We suggest a framework which uses GPT-4 to grade the content generated by these models as if those were stories written by students and graded by a (human) teacher. This new paradigm overcomes the flaws of standard benchmarks which often requires the model's output to be very structures, and moreover provides a multidimensional score for the model, providing scores for different capabilities such as grammar, creativity and consistency.   We hope that TinyStories can facilitate the development, analysis and research of LMs, especially for low-resource or specialized domains, and shed light on the emergence of language capabilities in LMs.

Name: depth_scaled_lr
Title: Depth-Scaled Learning Rates: Theory-Guided Layer-wise Optimization for Transformers
Problem Statement: Uniform learning rates across transformer layers ignore the differing learning requirements at different depths, potentially leading to suboptimal training dynamics.
Motivation: Deeper layers in transformers require more precise updates due to their role in learning complex abstractions, while shallow layers need larger updates for basic pattern recognition.
Proposed Method: Scale learning rates by 1/sqrt(layer_depth) for each transformer block, creating a natural decay that aligns with theoretical analysis of deep network optimization.
Experiment: Modify configure_optimizers() to create parameter groups with depth-scaled learning rates. Add tracking of layer-wise gradient statistics and attention pattern evolution during training. Compare against baseline with uniform learning rates across all metrics.

Name: dynamic_dropout_scheduling
Title: Dynamic Dropout Scheduling: Smoothed Validation-Guided Adaptive Regularization
Problem Statement: Fixed dropout rates throughout training may not optimally respond to the model's changing learning needs and can lead to suboptimal regularization.
Motivation: Models could benefit from adaptive regularization that responds to validation performance trends in a stable manner, avoiding noisy adjustments while still providing appropriate regularization when needed.
Proposed Method: Implement a dynamic dropout scheduler that adjusts dropout rates based on a smoothed average of validation loss trends. Use exponential moving averages to make adjustments more stable, increasing dropout when validation plateaus/increases and decreasing it when validation improves, within defined bounds.
Experiment: 1) Modify training loop to track smoothed validation loss via exponential moving average. 2) Add logic to adjust model.dropout based on these smoothed trends. 3) Add logging for dropout rate changes and smoothing values. 4) Compare against fixed dropout baselines on multiple datasets. Modifications needed in train() function's evaluation and main loop logic.

Name: learned_char_ngrams
Title: Learned Character N-gram Embeddings for Efficient Character-Level Modeling
Problem Statement: Character-level models process text inefficiently by treating each character independently, missing opportunities to leverage common character groupings.
Motivation: Learning embeddings for frequent character n-grams can improve efficiency while maintaining the benefits of character-level modeling, without requiring separate tokenization.
Proposed Method: Augment the character embedding layer with learned embeddings for common n-grams (2-4 characters). The model would use these n-gram embeddings when possible, falling back to single character embeddings for rare combinations.
Experiment: 1) Modify the embedding layer to include n-gram embeddings. 2) Add n-gram lookup during input processing. 3) Compare training speed and model performance against baseline. Key changes would be in the model initialization and forward pass preprocessing.

Title: Progressive Context Window: Curriculum Learning for Transformer Context Lengths
Problem Statement: Fixed context windows require transformers to learn both local and long-range dependencies simultaneously, potentially hindering efficient learning.
Motivation: Gradually increasing context length allows models to first master local patterns before tackling longer dependencies, mimicking human learning progression and potentially improving training efficiency.

Title: Co-occurrence Guided Attention: Leveraging Character Statistics for Better Initialization
Problem Statement: Character-level models lack initial linguistic knowledge about common character relationships, which could help bootstrap the learning process.

Experiment: 1) Add function to compute character co-occurrence statistics from training data. 2) Modify CausalSelfAttention to incorporate initial biases based on these statistics. 3) Add annealing schedule to reduce bias strength during training. 4) Compare training curves and final performance against baseline.

abstract: This paper aims to benchmark recent progress in language understanding models that output contextualised representations at the character level. Many such modelling architectures and methods to train those architectures have been proposed, but it is currently unclear what the relative contributions of the architecture vs. the pretraining objective are to final model performance. We explore the design space of such models, comparing architectural innovations and a variety of different pretraining objectives on a suite of evaluation tasks with a fixed training procedure in order to find the currently optimal way to build and train character-level BERT-like models. We find that our best performing character-level model exceeds the performance of a token-based model trained with the same settings on the same data, suggesting that character-level models are ready for more widespread adoption. Unfortunately, the best method to train character-level models still relies on a subword-level tokeniser during pretraining, and final model performance is highly dependent on tokeniser quality. We believe our results demonstrate the readiness of character-level models for multilingual language representation, and encourage NLP practitioners to try them as drop-in replacements for token-based models.

title: TinyHelen's First Curriculum: Training and Evaluating Tiny Language   Models in a Simpler Language Environment
abstract: Training language models (LMs) and their application agents is increasingly costly due to large datasets and models, making test failures difficult to bear. Simplified language environments serve as primordial training and testing grounds, retaining essential commonsense and communication skills but in a more digestible form, potentially enhancing the learning efficiency of LMs, and thus reducing the required model size and data volume for effective training and evaluation. In these simplified language environments, workable strategies for small models, datasets, and agents may be adaptable to larger models, datasets, and agents in complex language environments.   To create such environments, we focus on two aspects: i) minimizing language dataset noise and complexity, and ii) preserving the essential text distribution characteristics. Unlike previous methods, we propose a pipeline to refine text data by eliminating noise, minimizing vocabulary, and maintaining genre-specific patterns (e.g., for books, conversation, code, etc.). Implementing this pipeline with large LMs, we have created a leaner suite of LM training and evaluation datasets: 71M Leaner-Pretrain, 7M Leaner-Instruct, Leaner-Glue for assessing linguistic proficiency, and Leaner-Eval for testing instruction-following ability.   Our experiments show that leaner pre-training boosts LM learning efficiency. Tiny LMs trained on these datasets outperform those trained on original datasets in instruction-following across different language granularity levels. Moreover, the Leaner-Pretrain dataset's alignment with conventional large LM training sets enables resource-optimized analysis of how learning objectives, model architectures, and training techniques impact performance on language modeling and downstream tasks. Our code and datasets are available at https://github.com/EmpathYang/TinyHelen.git.

title: Toucan: Token-Aware Character Level Language Modeling
abstract: Character-level language models obviate the need for separately trained tokenizers, but efficiency suffers from longer sequence lengths. Learning to combine character representations into tokens has made training these models more efficient, but they still require decoding characters individually. We propose Toucan, an augmentation to character-level models to make them "token-aware". Comparing our method to prior work, we demonstrate significant speed-ups in character generation without a loss in language modeling performance. We then explore differences between our learned dynamic tokenization of character sequences with popular fixed vocabulary solutions such as Byte-Pair Encoding and WordPiece, finding our approach leads to a greater amount of longer sequences tokenized as single items. Our project and code are available at https://nlp.jhu.edu/nuggets/.

title: CharBERT: Character-aware Pre-trained Language Model
abstract: Most pre-trained language models (PLMs) construct word representations at subword level with Byte-Pair Encoding (BPE) or its variations, by which OOV (out-of-vocab) words are almost avoidable. However, those methods split a word into subword units and make the representation incomplete and fragile. In this paper, we propose a character-aware pre-trained language model named CharBERT improving on the previous methods (such as BERT, RoBERTa) to tackle these problems. We first construct the contextual word embedding for each token from the sequential character representations, then fuse the representations of characters and the subword representations by a novel heterogeneous interaction module. We also propose a new pre-training task named NLM (Noisy LM) for unsupervised character representation learning. We evaluate our method on question answering, sequence labeling, and text classification tasks, both on the original datasets and adversarial misspelling test sets. The experimental results show that our method can significantly improve the performance and robustness of PLMs simultaneously. Pretrained models, evaluation sets, and code are available at https://github.com/wtma/CharBERT

title: TinyStories: How Small Can Language Models Be and Still Speak Coherent   English?
abstract: Language models (LMs) are powerful tools for natural language processing, but they often struggle to produce coherent and fluent text when they are small. Models with around 125M parameters such as GPT-Neo (small) or GPT-2 (small) can rarely generate coherent and consistent English text beyond a few words even after extensive training. This raises the question of whether the emergence of the ability to produce coherent English text only occurs at larger scales (with hundreds of millions of parameters or more) and complex architectures (with many layers of global attention).   In this work, we introduce TinyStories, a synthetic dataset of short stories that only contain words that a typical 3 to 4-year-olds usually understand, generated by GPT-3.5 and GPT-4. We show that TinyStories can be used to train and evaluate LMs that are much smaller than the state-of-the-art models (below 10 million total parameters), or have much simpler architectures (with only one transformer block), yet still produce fluent and consistent stories with several paragraphs that are diverse and have almost perfect grammar, and demonstrate reasoning capabilities.   We also introduce a new paradigm for the evaluation of language models: We suggest a framework which uses GPT-4 to grade the content generated by these models as if those were stories written by students and graded by a (human) teacher. This new paradigm overcomes the flaws of standard benchmarks which often requires the model's output to be very structures, and moreover provides a multidimensional score for the model, providing scores for different capabilities such as grammar, creativity and consistency.   We hope that TinyStories can facilitate the development, analysis and research of LMs, especially for low-resource or specialized domains, and shed light on the emergence of language capabilities in LMs.

Name: difficult_transition_focus
Title: Difficult Transition Focus: Adaptive Training for Challenging Character Patterns
Problem Statement: Character-level models treat all character transitions equally during training, potentially spending too much capacity on easy patterns while struggling with linguistically challenging transitions.
Motivation: By identifying and focusing training on character transitions that are persistently difficult to predict, we can potentially accelerate learning of complex linguistic patterns while maintaining performance on simpler ones.
Proposed Method: Implement adaptive training that weights the loss function based on transition difficulty: 1) Track prediction confidence for all character transitions during training, 2) Identify persistently difficult transitions, 3) Gradually increase weight on difficult transitions in the loss function, 4) Maintain baseline performance through periodic full-sequence evaluation.
Experiment: 1) Add transition tracking to the training loop (modify forward/backward passes). 2) Implement dynamic loss weighting based on transition difficulty. 3) Add logging for difficult transition learning curves. 4) Compare against baseline on both difficult transitions and overall performance. Key changes would be in the loss calculation and training loop monitoring.

Title: Linguistic Unit Progression: Hierarchical Training for Character-Level Language Models

Name: character_position_learning
Title: Character Position Learning: Investigating and Improving Positional Encoding in Character-Level Models
Problem Statement: Current positional encoding schemes in transformers were designed for token-level modeling and may not optimally handle the finer granularity of character sequences.
Motivation: Character-level models process much longer sequences than token-level models, potentially requiring different approaches to positional encoding to effectively capture positional relationships at this granularity.
Proposed Method: 1) Analyze how standard positional embeddings evolve during character-level training, 2) Implement and evaluate relative positional encoding variants specifically designed for character sequences, 3) Compare their effectiveness through validation metrics and generation quality analysis.
Experiment: 1) Add tracking of positional embedding statistics during training, 2) Modify the positional embedding layer to implement relative position encoding variants, 3) Compare performance through validation loss and attention pattern analysis. Changes would be localized to the positional embedding implementation and training monitoring code.

title: TinyStories: How Small Can Language Models Be and Still Speak Coherent   English?
abstract: Language models (LMs) are powerful tools for natural language processing, but they often struggle to produce coherent and fluent text when they are small. Models with around 125M parameters such as GPT-Neo (small) or GPT-2 (small) can rarely generate coherent and consistent English text beyond a few words even after extensive training. This raises the question of whether the emergence of the ability to produce coherent English text only occurs at larger scales (with hundreds of millions of parameters or more) and complex architectures (with many layers of global attention).   In this work, we introduce TinyStories, a synthetic dataset of short stories that only contain words that a typical 3 to 4-year-olds usually understand, generated by GPT-3.5 and GPT-4. We show that TinyStories can be used to train and evaluate LMs that are much smaller than the state-of-the-art models (below 10 million total parameters), or have much simpler architectures (with only one transformer block), yet still produce fluent and consistent stories with several paragraphs that are diverse and have almost perfect grammar, and demonstrate reasoning capabilities.   We also introduce a new paradigm for the evaluation of language models: We suggest a framework which uses GPT-4 to grade the content generated by these models as if those were stories written by students and graded by a (human) teacher. This new paradigm overcomes the flaws of standard benchmarks which often requires the model's output to be very structures, and moreover provides a multidimensional score for the model, providing scores for different capabilities such as grammar, creativity and consistency.   We hope that TinyStories can facilitate the development, analysis and research of LMs, especially for low-resource or specialized domains, and shed light on the emergence of language capabilities in LMs.
